awd_titl_txt: Fourier and Fourier-type Algebras of Lie Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
Harmonic analysis is a fundamental branch of mathematics that addresses the following central problem: How can a function or signal be represented or approximated as a combination of basic waves? Such representations of signals are heavily used in today's technology for storage, transmission, and noise reduction of signals. Unfortunately, harmonic analytic methods perform poorly in various circumstances, as they are designed based on the assumption that the outcome of a series of actions is unchanged, regardless of the order in which the actions are performed. However, actions are often not interchangeable. For example, the result of performing consecutive rotations in three-dimensional (3D) space is highly sensitive to the order of rotations. Indeed, the real world is a very "non-commutative" universe. The space of 3D rotations is a simple example of a Lie group, which arise naturally in physics. This project will use techniques of functional analysis and Lie theory to advance the theory of non-commutative harmonic analysis for Lie groups. 

Fourier transforms and its analogues are the cornerstone of classical harmonic analysis. To generalize the concept of a Fourier transform to non-Abelian groups, the modern field of non-commutative harmonic analysis was initiated.  The broad philosophy here is to employ group representations and the theory of operators on Hilbert spaces to capture the non-Abelian nature of a group. A major trend in non-commutative harmonic analysis is to investigate function algebras related to the Fourier analysis (and representation theory) of non-Abelian groups. The Fourier algebra, which is associated with the regular representation of the ambient group, is a fundamental example of such function algebras. This project investigates Banach algebraic behavior, in particular derivation theory and spectral theory, of the Fourier algebra and its weighted versions for various classes of locally compact (Lie) groups. The ultimate goal is to investigate the connections between the Lie structure of a group and the Banach algebraic properties of its Fourier algebra. This project is jointly funded by the Analysis Program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we proposed to study Banach algebraic behavior of certain function algebras associated with a locally compact group, in particular the Fourier algebra and its weighted versions. These function algebras are central tools for developing Fourier analysis on non-Abelian topological groups assuming the role played by the Fourier transform in the classical case. Since a general non-Abelian group does not admit a Fourier transform, non-commutative harmonic analysis has been instead founded upon a representation theoretic point of view. The general philosophy here is to employ the theory of operators on Hilbert spaces to capture the non-commutative nature of a group. I have published 13 papers with the support of this grant and submitted 4 more manuscripts for journal publication. In addition, 3 PhD students and 1 undergraduate student working on different projects related to this proposal were partially supported with this grant. Finally, I developed and taught 3 PhD level courses on topics related to the subject of this project. Below, I summarize some of the new results obtained with the support of this grant. 

The natural interest in an analogous weighted theory for the non-commutative setting, which led to the definition of Beurling-Fourier algebras, was motivated by its potential connections and applications in weighted Fourier analysis. The definition of Beurling-Fourier algebra is a far-reaching generalization of the classical weighted L1-algebra, which in the fully non-commutative setting requires highly non-trivial Operator Algebra Theory. In the paper titled "Beurling-Fourier algebras on Lie groups and their spectra" (published in Advances in Mathematics) , we provide a thorough investigation of Beurling-Fourier algebras, a weighted version of Fourier algebras, on representative examples of connected Lie groups, and study the relation between the Gelfand spectrum of the Beurling-Fourier algebra of a (connected) Lie group, and its Lie group structure. Notably, we introduce a refined general definition of weights on the dual of locally compact groups and their associated Beurling-Fourier algebras, and provide three fundamental ways of constructing weights on the dual of a locally compact group. Finally, we focus our study on the cases of representative examples of Lie groups, namely SU(n), the Heisenberg group, the reduced Heisenberg group, the Euclidean motion group and its simply connected cover. We determine the spectrum of Beurling-Fourier algebras on each of the aforementioned groups emphasizing its connection to the complexification of underlying Lie groups.

In collaboration with Y. Choi and H.L. Pham, we studied approximately multiplicative functionals on weighted convolution algebras of semilattices, and the problem of whether all such functionals arise as small-norm perturbations of multiplicative ones, that is, if weighted convolution algebras of semilattices have stable characters. We characterized all weights on natural semilattices for which the weighted semilattice algebra has stable character property. More precisely, we showed that the weighted algebra has stable characters for every weight if and only if the natural semilattice has finite breadth. This answered an open question in the literature. To extend our results to all semilattices, we developed a new structure theory for infinite breadth semilattices which is of independent interest in combinatorics. 

Finally, as a part of this project I studied applications of noncommutative harmonic analysis to other fields such as graph signal processing. The field of signal processing on graphs was originally inspired by its applications in electrical engineering and image processing. Nowadays, graph signal processing has proved useful in many more disciplines. The spectral decomposition of graph adjacency matrices is an essential ingredient in the design of graph signal processing (GSP) techniques. With my students, I worked on providing explicit and detailed spectral decompositions of the adjacency matrix of a (weighted) Cayley graph, which results in a preferred basis. We used such bases to build frames that are suitable for developing GSP. In another collaborative work, we proposed GSP methods applicable to large graphs of similar structure. To this end, we extended a previous definition of graphon Fourier transform, and showed that the resulting graph Fourier transform is robust under the presence of noise. These findings are vital for developing cost-efficient signal processing techniques tailored for large and dynamic networks, such as those found in social or biological contexts.
